He pauses, horrified, seeing the scrap of cloth. He pulls it loose, turns back, screaming something in anguis ...and still more men come crashing into view, flooding b with dreamlike, slow-motion grace. ONE MAN is leading a t of DOGS, trying to untangle the leads. DEPUTY ROB McGEE i shouting for everybody to stay together... ...and under it all, we hear a sibilant, frightening whis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love your sister? You make any noise, know what happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And off that horrible voice, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOCK RADIO spews the morning weather report, abruptly pulling us into the present with a prediction of rain. PA EDGECOMB, late 70's/early 80's, wakes to another day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stands at his bathroom mirror, meticulously buttonin his shirt. He picks up a hairbrush, starts tidying his ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE OLD AND INFIRM haunt these corridors like ghosts. A W inches along on a walker. A MAN shuffles by with a rollin I.V. stand. The floor is a limey, institutional green. Paul comes into view, spry for his age, murmurs an occasi greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOZENS OF RETIREES are having breakfast, sipping weak cof or tea. Some chat and gossip, other are content to keep t own company, some just stare slackly into space. Paul enters, sees ELAINE CONNELLY sitting with a few othe ladies, sipping tea. She's 80, refined and elegant, his b friend here. She gives him a good-morning smile. He gives a rakish wink in return, which makes her smiles all the m Paul reaches past the people at the counter and sneaks tw pieces of cold leftover toast off a serving plate. He tos Elaine another look--catch ya later--and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul slips to the back door unnoticed. Identical red plas rain ponchos line the wall on pegs. He helps himself to o and eases outside, making good his escape.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Nestled in a valley of wooded hills, a drizzly mist rolli over the treetops. Paul appears f.g., coming up the ridge in his borrowed poncho. He looks back at the valley below, inhales deeply this is a man who loves his walks. He pulls a piece of toast from his pocket and starts to nibble as he presses up on the ridge... Low angle: nursing home and ridge beyond ...and we see Paul from a distance, just a speck trudging toward the treeline. A PICKUP TRUCK rumbles into frame an parks, a bumper sticker looming large: "I Have Seen God a His Name Is Newt Gingrich". BRAD DOLAN gets out, an orderly in his late 20's/early 30 arriving for work in jeans and cheesy plaid shirt. He gaz up toward the ridge, scowling and muttering softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the door and heads for the nursing home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as CAMERA BOOMS DOWN through the trees to find Paul wandering a wooded path, munching a tidbit of toast, look for all the world like Red Riding Hood in his plastic pon It's silent here, like a church. The only sounds we hear the twittering of the birds and the hammering of the woodpecker. A RUSTLING SOUND makes Paul freeze. He turns, becomes transfixed. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverse angle reveals a magnificent BUCK, not twenty feet away, misty breath punching the cold morning air. They watch each oth for an endless moment, both standing stock still... ...and then the animal bounds away, vanishing into the foliage. Paul lets out a breath, shakes his head in wonde He takes another bite of toast, moves on... ...and WE PAN WITH HIM to reveal a pair of old wooden sto shacks along the path up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark in here, cobwebby and decrepit. We see Paul approach outside the grimy window. He steps up to the glass and sh his eyes, peering curiously in as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul approaches the back door, returning from his walk. H reaches for the knob...and a figure in white lunges from behind the dumpster to grab his wrist. He whirls, gasping fright--it's Brad Dolan, wearing his orderly's uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out for a little stroll, Paulie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul tries to pull away, but Dolan's got him tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with this poncho you got on, huh? This isn't yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it off the wall there. There's a whole row of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for you, Paulie, that's the thing. Those are for the staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just borrowed it. Don't see what harm it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about harm, it's about rules. You probably don't think an old fart like you has to mind rules anymore, but that's just not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad's eyes keep shifting--he obviously doesn't mind abus the elderly as long as he doesn't get caught doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I broke the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no business up in those woods anyway, especially in the rain. What if you fall and bust a hip, huh? Who you think's gonna have to hoss your sorry old bacon back down here? Me, that's who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hurting me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do up there, anyway? You're too old to go jerk off, so what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just walk, that's all, I like to walk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad lashes out and grabs Paul's other hand, which he's b holding tightly clenched shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Open up. Let Poppa see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul uncurls his fingers, revealing the crushed remnants a bit of toast, his palm slick with a greasy oleo smear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn. Elaine stands just inside the screen door with cup of tea. Brad's eyes become calculated, wondering how she's seen. Elaine keeps her tone level, betraying nothin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you coming back, thought you'd like some tea. (beat) Are you coming in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dolan and I were...chatting. About the weather. I think we're through now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad lets Paul loose, leans close:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paulie? You tell anyone I squeezed your po' ol' hand, I'll tell 'em you're having senile delusions. Who you think they'll believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad walks off. Paul turns, watches him go. The screen do opens and Elaine steps out, her face pale. Paul gives her strained, though grateful, smile as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry Springer's on the tube, whipping his studio audienc into a frenzy. PAN OFF TO REVEAL DOZENS OF OLD FOLKS watc on couches and folding chairs. An old black fellow named is grousing to a GROUP OF ELDERLY LADIES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why we always watch this crap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting? Bunch'a inbred trailer trash, all they ever talk about is fucking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and WE CONTINUE PANNING to Paul and Elaine sitting nea the back, talking quietly as Paul rubs his bruised hand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should report him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might just provoke him all the more, make things worse for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not everybody he has it in for, Paul. It's you. (off his look) What did you do to provoke him in the first place? Nothing. He's just an abusive bully, and should be made to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is at the TV, switching channels while:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...no, the Movie Classic channel is further down...past the Home Shopping...keep going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds the Movie Classic channel, which is playing an o black and white musical--"Top Hat," with Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. A delighted reaction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! This is wonderful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul idly shifts his gaze to the TV...and his expression goes slack with recognition and dismay. Elaine sees the look i his eyes. He glances away...even briefly considers walking out...bu the end, he can't help himself. The past just caught up w him with a freight-train wallop, and, for one, he decides ride the rails... He looks back at the TV. On screen, Fred and Ginger have begun their famous "Cheek to Cheek" number, with Astaire singing in that sublime, easy-go-lucky way of his:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven, I'm in heaven...and my heart beat so that I can hardly speak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW PUSH IN on Paul, watching. He'd like to take his eye off the screen, but the movie has him in a grip tighter t Brad Dolan's. Elaine is watching him with puzzled concern

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. All he can hear is that music, all he can se are those dancers. The figures on TV are gliding with ghostlike grace in their silvery, phosphor-dot world of l ago... Paul abruptly bursts into tears. The room goes quiet, everything comes to a standstill. Al eyes turn, some concerned, others merely curious. Paul ju sits sobbing into his hands, shoulders heaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul...my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing over) What is it? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay...I'll be okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another orderly appears--Brad Dolan. He puts his hand on Paul's shoulder and leans close, feigning concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'matter, Paulie? Why the boo-hoo- hoo? Something nasty happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine shoves his hand away, eyes flashing with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Edgecomb will be perfectly fine without your help, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad back off with a "hey, suit yourself" gesture. Elaine helps Paul to his feet and leads him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is staring out the windows, pensive and drained. It' raining now, pattering the glass and the lawn beyond. Ela waits across from him, wishing he would speak. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess sometimes the past just catches up with you, whether you want it to or not. It's silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it the film? (off his look) It was, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't spoken of these things in a long time, Ellie. Over sixty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches out, gently takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul. I'm your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul wonders if he's even up to talking about it after al this time...and decides that perhaps he is:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ever tell you I was a prison guard during the depression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I mention I was in charge of death row? That I supervised all the executions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This does come as a surprise. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They usually call death row the Last Mile, but we called ours the Green Mile, because the floor was the color of faded limes. We had the electric chair then. Old Sparky, we called it. (beat) I've lived a lot of years, Ellie, but 1935 takes the prize. That was the year I had the worst urinary infection of my life. That was also the year of John Coffey, and the two dead girls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In blackness, a title card appears: "The Two Dead Girls"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUNDREDS OF PRISONERS work the fields, pickaxes rising an falling in waves, a prison song being sung in cadence wit the work. GUARDS patrol on horseback, rifles aimed at the A late 20's Ford PRISON TRUCK comes chugging into view al the road, kicking up a long trail of dust in the heat. It seems to be riding unusually low on its rear suspension.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A Depression-era prison in the south. The prison truck sw down the rutted dirt road toward the main gate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...while Paul Edgecomb, early 40's, stands in a cramped toilet in his guard's uniform, trying to piss. His face i pained, his forehead beaded with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUTUS HOWELL(nicknamed "Brutal" for his intimidating siz but he's actually rather thoughtful by nature) stands at entry door of the cellblock, peering out through a viewin slot. He sees the prison truck arrive at the main gate. He turns and nods to fellow guard DEAN STANTON sitting at duty desk, then cross the Green Mile--a wide corridor of faded green linoleum running some sixty paces top to bott with four large cells to a side. Brutal steps to the bathroom, listen a moment, knocks sof

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? Prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. Gimme a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal waits patiently, a bit embarrassed. He finally hea a THIN TRICKLE, accompanied by a stifled groan of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a man pissing razor blades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, revealing Paul's pale and sweaty face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should'a took the day off, gone to see the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a new arrival? You know better. Besides, it's not as bad as it was. I think it's clearing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hear the truck HONKING as it rumbles up outside. Pau gives them a nod to resume their positions. Paul walks do the Mile, passing the cells where two inmates reside--the first is ARLEN BITTERBUCK, a Washita Cherokee; the second EDUARD DELACROIX("DEL"), a skinny Cajun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New boy coming in, boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never you mind, Del, you just keep your nose quietly on your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul arrives at the end of the Mile, takes up a position an empty cell. (Down at this end, past the cells, is E Block's version of the "hole" -- a padded room where viol inmates are sent to cool off. It isn't used very often... fact, at the moment, it's doubling as storage space.) Brutal peers out the viewing slot as the truck stops outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, they're riding on the axle. What'd they do, bust the springs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUARDS PERCY WETMORE AND HARRY TERWILLIGER OF E BLOCK eme from the back of the truck and step down, turn back... Tighter angle on back of truck We get our first glimpse of the new inmate as a pair of GIGANTIC BLACK FEET step down into the yard...and the rea the truck bounces back up on its springs where it belongs Brutal sees what's coming, eyes widening slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? You might wanna reconsider getting in the cell with this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's enormous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be bigger than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal tosses him a look--just wait. He swings the door o in a hot flood of daylight, giving us our first good look John coffey is a huge black man, nearly 7 feet tall and 300 pounds, h massive head shiny and bald, his skin a tapestry of old scars, his prison overalls (the biggest size they had) en at mid-calf. He looks dull and confused, as if wondering where he is and how he got there. Percy and Harry lead hi toward E Block in shackles. Percy's got his hickory baton of it custom-made holster, hollering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead man walking! Dead man walking here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the cellblock Paul can't see them approach from where he stands, but he certainly hear Percy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeezus, pleeze-us, what the hell's he yelling about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up by the door, Brutal just rolls his eyes. Percy is the first one through the door, still hollering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead man walking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...then Coffey enters, ducking low to get through, his sh blotting out Brutal and Dean as his massive frame fills t door. Everything hangs suspended for a moment, a look of "hold shit" written on everybody's faces. Percy keeps yan on the big man's cuffs, leading him along with a cry of:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead man walking! Dead man--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy, that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy falls reproachfully silent. Paul doesn't dignify it just motions for them to come on. The procession comes do the Mile, with Brutal and Dean bringing up rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you wanna be in there with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks to Coffey) Am I gonna have trouble with you, big boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey shakes his head slowly. Paul takes the clipboard transfer papers from Harry, turns and enters the cell. Coffey just stands outside the cell and waits, as if he doesn't understand the concept. Paul motions him to come in. Coffey starts to comply, but Percy raps him smartly w the tip of his hickory baton to get him moving faster. Coffey flinches, enters the cell. Paul stares angrily at Percy, who stands slapping his hickory baton against the of his hand like a man with a toy he's itching to use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy. They're moving house over in the infirmary. Why don't you go see if they could use some help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got all the men they need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just go make sure? (off his look) I don't care where you go, Percy, as long as it's not here at this very moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy flushes red, the baton hovering near his palm. He l like he's about to say something, but thinks better of it stalks angrily up the Mile instead... ...and sees Del at his bars, smiling. Infuriated, Percy swings his baton and smashes Del's fingers with a LOUD CR Del jerks back, howling in pain:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OWW, GOD, HE BUS' MY FINGERS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wiped that grin off your shitpoke face, didn't I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Percy! Get the hell off my block!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy throws Paul a look of disdain--your block, huh? He swaggers out. Del's on his knees, weeping from the pain:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oww, damn, boss, he done bus' my fingers for true...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get it looked at, Del, now keep yourself quiet like I said!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del falls silent, moaning over his hand. Paul turns to Coffey, who looks unsettled by all the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I let Harry take those chains off you, you gonna be nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey nods. Harry enters to remove Coffey's shackles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is John Coffey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deep and quiet) Yes, sir, boss, like the drink, only not spelt the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you can spell, can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey shakes his head. Harry steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Paul Edgecomb. If I'm not here, you can ask for Mr. Terwilliger, Mr. Howell, or Mr. Stanton...those gentlemen there. (beat) This isn't like the rest of the prison. It's a quiet place, we like to keep it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey considers this carefully, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It weren't me making all the noise, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes narrowing) You having a joke on me, John Coffey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sees he isn't joking, continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your time here can be easy or hard, depends on you. If you behave, you get to walk in the exercise yard every day. We might even play some music on the radio from time to time. Questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey doesn't miss a beat, as if he's been waiting to as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you leave a light on after bedtime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul blinks. It's the last thing he expected. Coffey smil uneasily, as if they might think him foolish for asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I get a little scared in the dark sometimes. If it's a strange place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks to his men. The guards are trading glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty bright in here all night long. We keep half the lights burning in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cor'der.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey looks confused. Paul points to the lights lining t ceiling of the Green Mile in wire mesh cages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey nods, relieved. Then he surprises everybody by offering Paul his hand, as if to show proper manners. Pau hesitates, oddly touched, then surprised his men even mor accepting. Coffey's hand swallows his. Coffey shakes gent lets go. Paul steps from the cell. Brutal slides the door shut, lo it. Coffey stands a moment as if unsure what to do, then sinks onto the cot with his hands clasped between his kne He looks up at Paul, his voice soft as a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't help it, boss. I tried to take it back, but it was too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul turns, leads his men up the Mile...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL'S INNER OFFICE
dialogues.text: ...and they enter a few moments later. Paul is furious, b keeping a lid on his temper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean, run Delacroix up to the infirmary and see if his fingers are broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course they're broken, I heard the damn bones crack. Goddamn Percy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear what he was yelling when we brought the big dummy in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I miss it, Harry? The whole prison heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes Brutal snort, breaking the tension--the others can't help smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll probably have to answer for sending him off the Mile. He's gonna cause you trouble over this, you mark me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll chew that food when I have to. Right now I wanna hear about the new inmate...aside from how big he is, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Monstrous big. Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems meek enough. Looks like they sent us an imbecile to execute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imbecile or not, he deserves to fry for what he done. Here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry tosses a pair of manila envelopes bound with rubber bands on the desk before Paul--Coffey's file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...make your blood curdle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small are reserved for inmates of the Mile, fenced-off the main prison yard. Arlen Bitterbuck walks the perimete under the watchful eyes of guard BILL DODGE. We find Paul sitting by himself on the bleachers with Coffey's file on his knees, thoughtfully unwrapping his b bagged sandwich. PUSH SLOWLY IN as he begins to read...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and we see Klaus Detterick walk from his house to the with a milking pail, a solitary figure against a brighten horizon. He disappears into the barn... ...and we hold for a long moment, the house silent b.g.,chickens clucking and scratching in the front yard.. ...until a WOMAN'S SCREAM shatters the silence. Klaus reappears, dropping the pail, running toward the house...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL ON BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: ...as Paul turns the page, keeps reading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Klaus bursts in to find his wife MARJORIE absolute frantic with terror:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT? GOD SAKES, WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GIRLS! THE GIRLS ARE GONE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drags him through the house to a screened-off porch a where their 12 year old son HOWIE is pointing and shoutin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa! Papa, look! The blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and Klaus freezes there, stunned to see blood spattered the floor and the screen door hanging off its hinges...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL ON BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: ...as Paul absently takes another bite of his sandwich, n really tasting it, keeps reading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...plunging us back into the screaming chaos: Klaus grabb up shotgun shells, Howie loading the .22 rifle he got for Christmas, Marjorie sobbing incoherently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GODDAMN IT, WOMAN, GET ON THE PHONE NOW! YOU TELL 'EM WE HEADED WEST! MIND WHAT I'M SAYING! WEST, Y'HEAR?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and she goes stumbling through the house, grabbing for phone as her men disappear toward the porch b.g.:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Central! Central, are you on the line? Oh, God, please, somebody took my little girls...

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Klaus and his son race from the house, following spatters blood across the yard...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL ON THE BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: ...as Paul lets out a long breath, turns the page...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---and we see CARS AND TRUCKS pulling up, MEN jumping out with rifles, pouring down the incline toward the field wh Klaus is hollering and waving his arms. Deputy McGee come sliding down from the road, taking charge at the top of h lungs-- McGEE I WANT ALL THE WEAPONS UNLOADED, Y'HEAR? TAKE OUT YOUR SHELLS, I WON'T HAVE A MAN SHOT BY ACCIDENT TODAY! BOBO, WHERE THEM DOGS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and the dogs come bounding out of the back of a truck, howling down the incline to lead the chase...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...which takes us through the cattails and bulrushes...to spot where Klaus finds the little scrap of pale yellow fabric, turns and screams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, this belongs to my Katie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and they keep going, stopping abruptly as they find: A blood-drenched area of tramped grass. A little girl's blo nightgown hangs in the low branches of a tree. Some of th strong men look like they might throw up or faint at the sight of it. Their blood freezes in their veins as an INH HOWLING commences up ahead. It's like nothing they've eve heard before, raising the hackles of men and dogs alike.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL ON BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: ...as Paul quietly turns another page, shaking his head..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men reload their weapons. Everybody's terrified. McGe starts off, the other following his lead toward--

dialogues.speaker: THE RIVER
dialogues.text: --where they emerge from the treeline, drawing ever close the source of that INHUMAN HOWLING... ...and they stop, gazing in horror: John Coffey sits on the riverbank in bloody overalls, his huge feet splayed out before him. He's making that inhuma howling sound, face twisted in monstrous grief, pausing occasionally to take in a great hitching breath of air. Curled in his massive arms are the naked bodies of Detterick's 9 year-old twin girls, their once-blonde hair matted to their heads with blood. A tableau. The men staring. John Coffey howling. A train puffing smoke across the landscape. Klaus Detterick breaks the moment, lunging down the river in a headlong rush. The others try to grab him, but he sh them off and throws himself on Coffey with a scream of inarticulate rage, kicking and punching, fists flying. Co barely seems to notice. The others catch up with Klaus, drag him off. He falls to knees on the riverbank, sobbing into his hands. Howie run him, throws himself into his father's arm. They hug each other tightly, overwhelmed with grief. A semblance of quiet descends, except for Coffey's heartbroken wailing. A ring of rifle toting men forms aro him, though he hardly seems aware of it. McGee steps forw uncertain: McGEE Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey goes quiet at once, eyes still streaming tears. McGEE Mister? Can you hear me? (Coffey nods) You have a name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Coffey. Like the drink, only not spelt the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGee hunkers carefully down, watching for any sudden mov McGEE What happened here, John Coffey? You want to tell me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't help it. I tried to take it back, but it was too late. McGEE (pause) Boy, you are under arrest for murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGee spits in Coffey's face...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL ON BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: ...as Paul looks up with a slight start, jarred from his reading to find WARDEN HAL MOORES standing before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I interrupt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just about done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stows the file as Hal settles onto the bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that pretty gal of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melinda's not so well, Paul. Not so well at all. Got laid up with another headache yesterday. Worst one yet. She's also developed this weakness in her right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor still think it's migraines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal gives a slight shake of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be taking her up to Indianola next day or so for some tests. Had X-rays and the like. She is scared to death. Truth to tell, so am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's something they can see with an X-ray, maybe it's something they can fix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a letter, hands it to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This just came in. D.O.E. on Bitterbuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul glances toward Bitterbuck, scans the letter, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't come all the way down here just to hand me a D.O.E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I had an angry call from the state capital about twenty minutes ago. Is it true you ordered Percy Wetmore off the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you had reason, but like it or not, the wife of the governor of this state has only one nephew, and his name happens to be Percy Wetmore. I need to tell you how this lays out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Percy called his aunt and squealed like a schoolroom sissy. (Hal nods) He also mention he assaulted a prisoner this morning out of sheer petulance? Broke three fingers on Eduard Delacroix's left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear that part. I'm sure she didn't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is mean, careless, and stupid. Bad combination in a place like this. Sooner or later, he's gonna get somebody hurt. Or worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Brutus Howell will make sure that doesn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy enough to say. We can't watch him every minute, Hal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick with it. May not be much longer. I have it on good authority that Percy has an application in at Briar Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mental hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Administration job. Better pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why's he still here? He could get that application pushed through...hell, with his connections, he could have any state job he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal has no answer. Paul look off toward Bitterbuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what I think. I think he just wants to see one cook up close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal follows Paul's gaze, takes his meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he'll get his chance then, won't he? Maybe then he'll be satisfied and move on. In the meantime, you'll keep the peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal rises, slapping yard dust off his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give Melinda my love, okay? I bet that X-ray turns out to be nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks off looking like he's got the weight of the wor on his shoulders. Paul looks at the letter again...

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON LETTER
dialogues.text: ...which is head: Date Of Execution."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is at the kitchen table in the wee hours of the morn drinking buttermilk and listening to SOFT MUSIC on the ra JANICE EDGECOMB appears, shuffling sleepily downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you. Music too loud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There's just this big empty spot in the bed where my husband usually sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to tell you he's having a little trouble with that tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes into the kitchen, strokes his hair. There's an familiarity and a deep love between these two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worried about Melinda and Hal? Is that what's got you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that. Things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits on his lap and gives him a crooked smile--you're getting off that easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a new inmate today. Big, simple-minded fella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I want to hear what he did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. One sleepless member of this family's enough. (softly) The things that happen in this world. It's a wonder God allows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a tiny kiss above his left eyebrow, in that special spot that makes him prickle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come to bed? I've got something to help you sleep, and you can have all you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I wish. I've still got something wrong with my waterworks, I don't want to pass it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see Doc Sadler yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, because he'll want me to take sulfa tablets and I'll spend the rest of the week puking in every corner of my office. It'll run its course all by itself, thank you very much for your concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses that spot above his eyebrow again. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor old guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN TIGHT ANGLES: Copper plugs are cleaned, switches are oiled, circuits are tested...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as maintenance is performed on Old Sparky by JACK VAN and a small crew. Paul is carefully sanding a connector p Dean is waxing Old Sparky's wooden arms to a gleam. Paul and Dean pause, thinking they hear a LAUGH drifting from E Block...and then Brutal calls softly to them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? Dean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Dean enter to find Brutal trying not to wake the cons in their cells by laughing too loudly. They follows gaze down the Mile, see nothing, turn to him like he's cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess the legislature loosened those purse-strings enough to hire on a new guard. (off their looks) Look again. He's right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Dean look again and this time they see it: A tiny brown mouse is coming up the Mile. It trots a shor distance, peers right and left as if checking the snoring inmates in their cells, then makes another forward spurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's doing a cell check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gets them all trying not to laugh. The mouse draws e closer. Dean starts to look worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't normal for a mouse to come up on people that way. Maybe it's rabid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my Christ. The big mouse expert. The Mouse Man. You see it foaming at the mouth, Mouse Man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubious) I don't see its mouth at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it--Paul and Brutal burst out laughing. The mou stops before them and peers up, curling its tail primly around its paws as if to wait. The guards fall silent, fascinated. Bitterbuck stirs in his cell, sits up to watc Brutal tears off a piece of his half-eaten corned beef sandwich, holds it delicately out with two fingers. The m rises up, appraising the morsel with shiny black eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Brutal, no! We'll be hip-deep in mice around here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Paul) I just wanna see what he'll do. In the interests of science, like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul shrugs. Brutal drops the scrap. The mouse grabs it a eats, sitting up like a dog doing a trick. The mouse turns and scurries back down the Mile, vanishin under the restraint room door at the far end. Dean throws Paul an "I told you so" look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the damn restraint room. You know he's gonna be chewing the padding out of walls and making himself a nice little nest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal give Paul a sheepish look--well? Paul sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Let's get the damn mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stride grimly down the Mile to the restraint room do men on a mission. Coffey's awake now, peering from his co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw me a mouse go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a dream. Go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't no dream. It was a mouse all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't put anything over on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul unlocks the door, revealing a padded room filled wit storage: cleaning supplies, buckets of paint, mops and ladders, you name it. Brutal shrugs off his jacket. Paul grabs a mop from a steel bucket, hands it to Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean, watch the door. He tries to get past you, whack him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal or the mouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Har har, Mouse Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal and Paul start doing the heavy lifting, muscling a unused filing cabinet out the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and they finally relay the last few heavy buckets of p onto the Mile. Paul and Brutal catch their breath, scanni the empty restraint room. Their eyes go glaringly to Dean

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let him get past you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I didn't, I was here all the time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then where the hell is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move slowly into the room, peering into every nook a cranny, utterly mystified. Brutal shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three grown men. Outsmarted by a mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, bright side is, all this commotion probably scared him off for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right. That's the last we'll see of him...

dialogues.speaker: IN BLACKNESS, A TITLE CARD APPEARS
dialogues.text: "The Mouse on the Mile"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low, static shot. Green floor stretching before us. Har and Bill Dodge are at the desk b.g., doing paperwork and filing chores. Percy is idling nearby, whistling softly a combing his hair... ...and into this quiet shot, deep in foreground, creeps t mouse. He starts walking the Mile as before... ...right toward Percy.

dialogues.speaker: COFFEY
dialogues.text: stares through his bars as the mouse goes by...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: keeps combing his hair, unaware...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: sits quietly picking his nose in his cell. The mouse appe outside the bars, cruising inexorably up the Mile. Del tu slowly, watches the mouse go by...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: still grooming himself, still unaware...

dialogues.speaker: THE MOUSE
dialogues.text: keeps coming closer. ANGLE UP to Bitterbuck peering throu his bars, watching him go by...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: keeps working that comb--and freezes at the sound of a TI SQUEAK. His head swivels slowly... ...and there's the mouse. Staring at him. That moment of eye contact reveals an enmity older than t itself. If mice have a natural enemy, Percy is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Bill glance up from their work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be damned. There he is, big as Billy-be-frigged. I thought Brutal was pulling my leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a goddamn mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Brute said he was in here last night begging for food, came right up to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ass. Give him some room, Percy, see what he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy takes a few careful steps back, eyes never leaving mouse. (Percy's hand starts easing toward the handle of h baton.) The mouse comes up to the desk as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brave little bastard, gotta give him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry breaks off a small piece of cracker and drops it. T mouse picks it up, starts to eat. (Percy's hand inches ev closer to his baton).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, lemme try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill drops a piece of cracker. The mouse ignores it completely, keeping its beady little eyes on Harry. (Perc hand starts easing his baton from its holster.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Maybe he knows you're just a floater. Gotta be an E Block regular to feed the E Block mouse, don'cha know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry drops another piece--and sure enough, the mouse sta to eat. Harry's smile fades. He and Bill trade a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just kidding ab--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy lets rip a BELLOWING WAR CRY ("Yaaaahhh!") and laun his baton like a spear, scaring the crap out of everyone. The mouse ducks (yes, actually ducks) and the baton sail his head close enough to ruffle its fur, bouncing off the floor. Apparently remembering a pressing engagement elsewhere, the mouse takes off in a flash toward the restraint room. Percy roars with frustration and takes off after it, tryi to squash it with his heavy work shoes, leaping and stomp with great big galloping strides, missing the mouse by inches... ...and thus is the Green Mile traversed, with Percy stomp and hollering like a spastic flamenco dancer, the convict yelling at their bars, the mouse zigging and zagging like Thorpe heading for the endzone... The mouse wins, zipping to safety under the restraint roo door. Percy pounds his fist against the door in frustrati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fumbles with his keys, unlocks the door, yelling all t while:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'M GONNA RIP YOUR DISEASED HEAD OFF, YOU LITTLE PIECE OF SHIT!

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE E BLOCK
dialogues.text: Paul and Brutal are arriving for work--they pause, hearin PERCY'S YELLS drifting from the windows. The regular CONS the yard are drifting curiously to the fence, wondering i riot's brewing. Paul and Brutal take off running--

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE E BLOCK
dialogues.text: --and rush in to find:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy met your mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry points. Percy's down at the far end, rummaging wild in the restraint room, tossing shit out onto the Mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in here somewhere! I'm gonna squish the little son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts muscling the filing cabinet out the door, kicki buckets out of his way. Brutal calls out to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy, we already tried that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Whad'ja say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stops Brutal with a look--don't you dare stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --uh, knock yourself out. Hope you nail the bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul crosses his arms and smiles, leans back against the to wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Percy hauls the last of the stuff out, exhausted. steps back in and looks around, unable to believe there's mouse cowering in the corner. Paul and the men approach, keeping straight faces, navigating the crap in the corrid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh. Ain't in there, huh? Don't that beat the mousie band?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy keeps scanning the restraint room. The others all l to Paul, waiting for him to speak--you're the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy. You want to think about what you were doing just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns, glaring) I know what I was doing. Trying to get the mouse. You blind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You also scared the living crap out of me and Bill. And them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cocks a thumb at the inmates in their cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? They aren't in cradle- school, case you didn't notice... (directed at Paul) ...although you treat them that way half the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't scare 'em any more than we have to, Percy. They're under enough strain as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men under strain can snap. Hurt themselves. Hurt others. That's why our job is talking, not yelling. You'll do better to think of this place like an intensive care ward in a hospital--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think of it as a bucket of piss to drown rats in. That's all. (scans their faces) Anybody doesn't like it can kiss my ass. How's that sit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal steps forward, wanting to slug the little bastard. Percy shies back, but keeps his bravado up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it. You'll be on the bread lines before the week is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all know who your connections are, Percy... (steps close) ...but you ever threaten a man on this block again, we're all gonna have a go. Job be damned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big talk. You done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get all this shit back in the restraint room. You're cluttering up my Mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn and walk away, leaving Percy as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SLOW TRACKING SHOT OF THE GREEN FLOOR takes us past a t scrap of break...and then another...and then past a mouse primed with a scrap of bacon... ...and we keep following a long trail of bread scraps and mousetraps until we come to Percy, alone on the Mile, carefully laying the last mousetrap down... ...and he scoots back against the desk to wait, crouched holding his breath, eyes riveted to the restraint room do for any sign of his furry nemesis... ...and CAMERA BOOMS SLOWLY DOWN off his face, dipping dow floor level... ...where the mouse is revealed under the desk, peering in same direction as Percy, wondering what the hell's so interesting down there. It hops further out to see...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FROM FLOOR LEVEL
dialogues.text: ...and the mouse enters frame, hopping out a few more ste mouse and man staring in the same direction. A long beat. Percy turns, looks down at the mouse. The mo turns, looks up at Percy... ...and all hell breaks loose again. They race the Mile as before, Percy hollering and stomping all the way, mousetr snapping and flying up into frame as they go charging wil past the cells. The mouse wins again. Percy pauses, furious...and sees Co staring at him from his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw me a mouse go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy loses it, kicking and punching the restraint room d in a screaming rage as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul appears at Bitterbuck's bars with a group of guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlen? Your daughter and her family are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitterbuck steps from his cell. Bill Dodge escorts him of the block. The moment they're gone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's move. I want at least two rehearsals before he gets back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitterbuck is led in. His DAUGHTER rises...an awkward hesitation...and she touches his face, kisses him. He tak her hands, kisses them, tries not to cry. The rest of the family is there: SON-IN-LAW, GRANDCHILDREN, COUSINS. They form around him, murmuring hellos, shaking hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...while TOOT-TOOT takes Bitterbuck's place in the cell. a wiry and toothless old trusty, crazy as a tick. He sits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sittin' down, sittin' down, rehearsing now! Everybody settle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances to Paul--okay, hit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlen Bitterbuck, step forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toot springs to his feet and steps from the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm steppin' forward, I'm steppin' forward, I'm steppin' forward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toot turns, shows the top of his head to Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is his head properly shaved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's dandruffy and it smells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that for a yes. All right, Arlen, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toot starts up the corridor, ringed by guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm walkin' the Mile, I'm walkin' the Mile, I'm walkin' the Mile...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL'S INNER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Toot throws himself to his knees as soon as they enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm prayin', I'm prayin', I'm prayin'. The Lord is my shepherd, so on an' so forth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toot, you have to wait till I tell you to pray. (Toot waits) Okay, pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still prayin', still prayin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, we're not gonna have some Cherokee medicine man in here whoopin' and hollerin' and shaking his dick, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still prayin', prayin', gettin' right with Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it quietly, you old gink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry slaps Toot upside the head to shut him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I was saying, I don't believe they actually shake their dicks, Harry. Be that as it may, Mr. Bitterbuck is a Christian, so we got Reverend Schuster coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's good. Fast, too. Doesn't get 'em worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your feet, Toot. You've prayed enough for one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin' to my feet, walkin' again, walkin' on the Green Mile...

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTION CHAMBER
dialogues.text: They enter. Brutal is waiting for them, gun drawn. Percy peers out from behind the partition wall from the switch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch and learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul motions Percy behind the wall. Percy sighs, takes hi spot next to Jack Van Hay, peers through the wire mesh as Toot plops into Old Sparky, wriggling his skinny ass to g comfy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sittin' down, sittin' down, takin' a seat in Old Sparky's lap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Dean kneel to apply the ankle clamps. Brutal ste in from the side, pressing down on the condemned man's le arm to keep him in place until the ankle clamps are secur Harry moves in from the other side, securing the right ar clamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin' clamped, gettin' clamped, gettin'--ow, shit, watch the skin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul signals "ankles secure." Brutal holsters his pistol, applies the final clamp to the left arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll on one.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE PARTITION
dialogues.text: Van Hay mimes turning the generator knob up, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Roll on one" means I turn the generator up full. You'll see the lights go brighter in half the prison...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME MAIN CHAMBER
dialogues.text: as Brutal steps before the "condemned" and pronounces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlen Bitterbuck, you have been condemned to die by a jury of your peers, sentence imposed by a judge in good standing in this state. Do you have anything to say before the sentence is carried out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gleefully) Yeah! I want a fried chicken dinner with gravy on the taters, I want to shit in your hat, and I got to have Mae West sit on my face, because I am one horny motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal tries to hold on, but it's impossible--he cracks u Everybody falls apart, howling helplessly with laughter. Jack Van Hay is guffawing behind his partition. Only Paul is reining it in--he's a little too pissed to g with it. He waits until the laughing fit starts to pass,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Brutal. That goes for everybody. I want quiet in here. (turns) Toot, another remark like that, I'll have Van Hay roll on two for real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, gently) It was pretty funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I don't like it. Tomorrow night we're doing this for real. I don't want somebody remembering a stupid joke like that and getting going again. (off their looks) Ever try not laughing in church once something funny gets stuck in your head. Same goddamn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Paul. You're right. Let's keep going. Harry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry takes a black mask and snugs it down over Toot's he leaving only the crown of his head exposed. Brutal takes large sponge, dips it in a steel bucket, mimes soaking it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the sponge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You soak it in brine, get it good and wet. Conducts the electricity directly to the brain, fast like a bullet. You don't ever want to throw the switch on a man without that.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME MAIN CHAMBER
dialogues.text: as the sponge is placed atop Toot's head. Harry now lower the steel cap and Brutal secures the straps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlen Bitterbuck, electricity shall now be passed through your body until you are dead, in accordance with the state law. God have mercy on your soul. (to Van Hay) Roll on two.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE PARTITION
dialogues.text: Van Hay mimes flipping the switch, looks to Percy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's that.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME MAIN CHAMBER
dialogues.text: Toot can't resist--he starts bucking and flailing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm fryin'! Fryin'! Geeaaah! Fryin' like a done tom turkey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul rolls his eyes at Brutal. Brutal shifts his gaze pas him and nods--look behind you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the witnesses showed up a day early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul turns. Sitting on the door sill, watching them with beady eyes, is the mouse. Paul turns back, addresses the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's go again and do it right this time! Get that idiot out of the chair...

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTION CHAMBER
dialogues.text: Brutal and Harry start undoing Toot's clamps. Everybody relaxes, drifting from their positions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the room is now quietly filling up with WITNESSES trickling in. People speak in whispers, if at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitterbuck, the top of his head now shaved, is speaking quietly as Paul listens:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think if a man sincerely repents on what he done wrong, he might get to go back to the time that was happiest for him and live there forever? Could that be what heaven is like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul doesn't think so--but that's not what Bitterbuck nee to hear, so the lie comes easy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just about believe that very thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Bitterbuck smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had me a young wife when I was eighteen. Spent our first summer in the mountains. Made love every night. She'd just lie there after, bare-breasted in the firelight, and we'd talk sometimes till the sun come up. (beat) That was my best time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal appears at the door, checks his pocketwatch, nods Paul. Bitterbuck takes a deep breath, getting himself rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be fine. You'll do fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SPONGE is pulled sopping wet from the bucket of brine dripping a trail of water across the floor. Brutal places atop Bitterbuck's head. Water courses down the sides of t condemned man's mask and neck, pooling on the floor. The cap is lowered, the straps secured. All we hear now i the sound of Bitterbuck's BREATHING growing louder and fa under the mask...until, softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll on two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM! The switch is thrown. Bitterbuck surges forward aga the straps, riding the powerful current. Some witnesses turn away. Paul and Brutal maintain grim e contact with each other, waiting. Behind the partition, Percy watches through the mesh with gleaming eyes, wishing he could see better. Van Hay kills the current. Bitterbuck goes limp. A DOCTOR steps forward, checks for a heartbeat, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The switch is thrown a second time. Bitterbuck surges for again, riding the current all the way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitterbuck's dead face stares up at us from a gurney. A h reaches down, gives his cheek a squeeze. TILT UP to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adios, Chief. Drop us a card from hell, let us know if it's hot enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal knocks Percy's hand away, shoves him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's paid what he's owed. He's square with the house again, so keep your goddamn hands off him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws the sheet over Bitterbuck's face, wheels the gur down the tunnel. Percy throws a look to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up his ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Percy. Always you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul brushes past him, but:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta hate the new boy? That the way it is around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns back) Why not just move on? Go to Briar Ridge. (off his look) Yeah, I know about it. Sounds like a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might take it, too. Soon as you put me out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul cocks his head--excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me. I want Brutal's spot for the next execution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) What's with you? Seeing a man die isn't enough? You gotta be close enough to smell his nuts cook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna be out front, is all. Just one time. Then you'll be rid of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I say no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might just stick around for good, make me a career of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul just shakes his head in wonder and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey's lying on his bunk, weeping quiet tears. He stirs the sound of GIGGLING. He sits up, peers curiously throug the bars. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del?

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GUARD STATION
dialogues.text: Paul glances up from writing in the daily log. Silence no He goes back to writing--and the GIGGLING comes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix? That you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Just more giggling. Paul rises, walks down the Mile to Delacroix's cell--and stops, staring in through t bars.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL'S INNER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Brutal and Dean are having lunch. Paul pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not gonna believe this.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME E BLOCK
dialogues.text: The men follow Paul onto the Mile. By now, Del is CACKLIN WILDLY in his cell. Brutal shoots Paul a look--has he gon insane? Paul gestures "see for yourself." They arrive at the bars...and find the mouse sitting on D shoulder. Del looks up, giggling like a kid at Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! I done tame me dat mouse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch dis! Watch what he do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stretches out his left arm. The mouse crawls over the of his head, scampers along his arm to the wrist, turns around and scampers back. The guards just stand there, staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't he sumpthin now? Ain't Mr. Jingles smart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jingles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dat his name. He whisper it in my ear. Cap'n, can I have a box for my mouse so he can sleep in here wi' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I notice your English gets better when you want something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna see what else he can do? Watch, watch, watch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the mouse on the floor, grabs a small wooden spoo The mouse sees it, poises like a man getting ready for a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We play fetch, Mr. Jingles? We play fetch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the spool across the floor, bounces it against wall. The mouse goes after it like a dog after a stick--a proceeds to push it back to the bunk, rolling it with its front paws all the way to Delacroix's feet. By now, the guard's jaws are hanging open. Paul's got a f little chill running up his spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fetch it ever' time. Smart as hell, ain't he? We do da trick again, watch, watch, watch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again he throws the spool. Again the mouse goes after it, starts rolling it back. Del howls with laughter, claps hi hands like a kid. Brutal murmurs to the others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's training who here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's some smart mouse, Del. Like he's a circus mouse or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circus mouse! Dat jus' what he is, too! A circus mouse! I get outta here, he make me rich, see if he don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the spool again, makes a drumroll sound, toss it. The mouse does its thing, rolling the spool back... ...as Percy enters the scene. Del catches sight of him an scoops up his mouse, drawing fearfully back on his bunk. tries to hide Mr. Jingles in his hands--but the mouse wriggles from his grasp and scampers up on top of his hea where he regards Percy with mistrustful, beady mouse eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well. Looks like you found yourself a new friend, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del tries to offer some defiance--but all he can manage i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don' hurt him, 'kay? 'kay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy shrugs as if to say "no skin off me", looks to Paul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the one I chased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (level) Yes, that's the one. Only Del says his name is Mr. Jingles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul trades a look with the others, everybody wondering j what the hell's going through Percy's mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del was just asking for a box. He thinks the mouse will sleep in it, I guess. That he might keep it for a pet. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it'll shit up his nose some night and run away, but I guess that's Del's lookout. (beat) We oughtta find a cigar box. Get some cotton batting from he dispensary to line it with. That should do real nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy walks away, leaving them dumbstruck. Paul turns to others. Of all the things they've seen in the last few minutes, Percy being nice is the most amazing of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man said get a cigar box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul comes up the stairs to the warden's office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and enters to find Hal staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal? You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Paul. Close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal's speech is halting, his thoughts disjointed and slow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh. So you know. You got a new prisoner coming in tomorrow. William Wharton. Young kid. Wild as hell, judging from this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the report, trying to focus his thoughts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...been rambling all over the state last few years, causing all kinds of trouble. Finally hit big time. Killed three people in a holdup, including a pregnant woman. Got "Billy the Kid" tattooed on his left arm...bad news all around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trails off, no longer able to focus on the words. Paul shocked to see tears spill silently down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tumor, Paul. A brain tumor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul doesn't know what to say. Hal looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got X-ray pictures of it. It's the size of a lemon, they said, and way down deep inside where they can't operate. They say she'll be dead by Christmas. I haven't told her. I can't think how. For the life of me, Paul, I can't think how to tell my wife she's going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal Moores, one of the toughest and steadiest men you'd e meets, starts to cry. He dissolves into great big gasping sobs, losing all control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul lies awake, watching Jan sleep. He looks troubled--n to mention feverish. It occurs to him how badly he has to pee. He sits up, clutching at a queasy stab of pain in hi groin...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM STAIRS
dialogues.text: ...and comes hurrying down the steps, clutching himself..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and he's moving even faster as he exits the kitchen, racing for the outhouse. He realizes he's not going to ma it, stops to piss near the woodpile at the corner of the house... ...and as he does, he's hit with the most stunning pain o his life. He buckles to his knees--it's only his flailing hand against the woodpile that prevents him from going fa first into his own piss. He crams his other hand to his m in an enormous effort not to scream and wake his wife. He manages to ride it out until his bladder empties. He f onto his side, rolls over on the grass, and stares up at sky with both hands pressed to his groin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...oh God...oh God...

dialogues.speaker: IN BLACKNESS, A TITLE CARD APPEARS
dialogues.text: "Coffey's Hands"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks feverish and clammy as he buttons up his unifo jacket. Jan is packing his lunch, throwing him looks, kno how sick he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the doctor. I'm going. (off her look) Today. Just as soon as we get the new inmate squares away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him his brown-bagged lunch, kisses his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a tattoo: "Billy the Kid." TILT UP to WILLIAM WHAR staring out the window, wearing a hospital gown, his face utterly blank. He looks heavily medicated. Harry, Dean, and Percy enter. Billy doesn't react, just k staring out. Harry waves his fingers in Billy's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy's doped to the gills. Dean, hand me them clothes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean relays some folded prison clothes to Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Wharton! Hey! I'm talking to you! Put these clothes on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy turns with a vacant look, takes the clothes. He fum with the shirt, drops the pants. Harry and Dean sigh. They strip Billy's hospital gown off and proceed to put t shirt on him, guiding his limp arms through the sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hellraiser, huh? Looks more like a limp noodle to me. Hey! Hey, you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy looks up, meets Percy's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been declared competent! Know what that means? Mean's you're gonna ride the lightning, son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy does a quick impression of a man jittering and jerk in the electric chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bzzzzzzzzt-zap! Just like that! How's it feel to know you're gonna die with your knees bent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Percy, give us a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing, Percy picks up the pants. They proceed to help Billy into them one leg at a time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is trying to piss. Except for a few drops hitting th bowl, excruciating pain seems to be the only result. He g up, grabs a towel, wipes the sweat from his feverish face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and steps gingerly from the toilet. Del's watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don' look so good, boss. Look like you runnin' you a fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul shoots him a baleful look--no kidding. Another voice calls softly from further down the Mile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Edgecomb? Needs ta see you down here, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got things to tend to just now, John Coffey. You be still in your cell now, y'hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey falls silent. Paul goes to the entrance door and p through the viewing slot, anxious to have this over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prison truck appears, swaying along the rutted road..

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TRUCK
dialogues.text: ...while Billy Wharton stares at nothing, drool dripping his slack mouth in long strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul watches the truck pull in. He draws away from the sl proceeds toward the empty cell which used to be Bitterbuck's...

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK
dialogues.text: The rear doors are swung open. Harry emerges. Dean and Pe are guiding Billy by the arm, helping him down...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE E BLOCK
dialogues.text: Paul waits at the empty cell. ANGLE PANS TIGHT to Coffey his bars, eyes widening in a blossoming of some nameless or dread. Something bad's coming. A whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE E BLOCK
dialogues.text: Billy is brought to the door. Dean pulls his keys, starts unlock it. We PUSH IN on Billy's face, where the tiniest trace of a smile is starting to grow...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE E BLOCK
dialogues.text: ...and Coffey's unease grows with it. he presses his face the bars, his whispering becoming more urgent:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful. Careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hears him, glances back with a puzzled look. Coffey' gaze is directed at the door, which is being unlocked...

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: ...and opened. In that moment, the slack look on Billy's gives way to a wild grin. A CRAZED SCREECH leaps from his throat, a cross between a rebel yell and a dog being tortured, freezing everybody's blood in their veins--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeeeeeeehaaaawwwwwwrooooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and he drops his wrist-chain down over Dean's head, jer it tight, begins to strangle him. Dean lurches forward, B riding/propelling him through the door onto the Mile. Percy stands frozen in the doorway, stunned. Harry shoves aside and jumps on Billy from behind, trying to get him o Dean. Dean is choking, turning purple. Paul rushes from the cell to join the fray. Billy whirls, delivering a stunning kick to Paul's groin. Paul's bladde pain goes nuclear--he falls back in agony, clutching hims and sucking air through his teeth, unable even to scream. Billy rams an elbow into Harry's face, knocks him sprawli on the desk, screaming and laughing and howling all the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOOEE, BOYS! AIN'T THIS A PARTY, NOW? IS IT, OR WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul forces himself to his feet, pulls his revolver, draw down on Billy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LET HIM GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but Billy jerks Dean around, using him as a shield...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G'WAN, SHOOT! SEE WHO YA HIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean is choking, dying. Paul is shifting his aim, trying a clear shot, not getting one. Percy's still just inside doorway, pressed against the wall with fear...
