dialogues.text: ...while TOWER GUARDS huddle in their enclosure atop the walls. An occasional SPOTLIGHT cuts the darkness. FIREFLI dance in the fields and trees as far as the eye can see. Four dark figures detach from the shadows, hurrying acros the lonely country road into the fields on the far side..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey's hand scoops up some fallen leaves. TILT UP to hi face as he crunches them under his nose, inhaling their s He see the guards throwing him anxious looks. He misreads this, holds out his hand so they can smell too. They do i just to make him happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, big boy, keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEW FIREFLIES come winking through frame as the group presses on...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER AREA/WOODS
dialogues.text: The trees are growing sparser, opening onto fields. MORE FIREFLIES are flitting into view, trailing in their wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just up ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry brings them to a thicket of trees. They start remov branches and boughs, uncovering a battered old FARMALL TR hidden in the brush. The men pause. Even more fireflies are swirling around th growing in number. It's getting downright weird. Coffey laughs softly, drawing their attention. A childlik smile has utterly transformed his face. He raises his han letting a firefly weave playfully in and out of his finge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there, little firefly. Where's Mrs. Firefly this evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another firefly joins the first, both now dancing and blinking around his fingers. Coffey laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there you is. You come out to play too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men stand gaping. The fireflies are flitting to Coffe if to a beacon. He waves his hands slowly, fireflies blin and trailing from his fingertips like magic dust. They begin orbiting his shiny bald head like tiny glowing planet orbiting a sun, their light kicking a mellow sheen his ebony skin. Coffey's eyes meet Paul's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem...drawn to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love 'em, is why. They don't think no hurtful thoughts. They's just happy to be. Happy little lightning bugs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men don't know whether to be enchanted or terrified. Harry gives Paul a look--can we go? Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, big boy. Upsy-daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey clambers up on the stakebed. Paul and Brutal join Harry gets in behind the wheel, jabs the starter button..

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STAKEBED
dialogues.text: ...while Coffey sits with his back to the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John? Do you know where we're taking you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help a lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Help a lady. But how did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno. Tell the truth, boss, I don't know much'a anything. Never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck pulls out. Coffey waves as the fireflies get le behind, dwindling away like stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, fireflies. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRYSIDE
dialogues.text: The truck rumbles from the fields onto a dirt road, count fireflies swirling in its wake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlights come over the rise. The truck appears, rumblin down toward the house. The world is isolated and still.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TRUCK CAB
dialogues.text: Harry stops and cuts the engine, leaving the headlights o Silence now, save for the trilling of crickets.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STAKEBED
dialogues.text: Paul and Brutal both look terrified now that they're actu here. An urgent whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can still turn back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hesitates, wanting to do just that, but:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss, look. Someone's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights are coming on inside the house. Coffey rises and s down from the truck, pulling Paul along. Brutal follows t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a mistake. Christ, Paul, what were we thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late now. Harry, keep John here until we call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Brutal walk to the front door as the lights insi the house keep clicking on. The last one finally comes on over the stoop, the front door opens a crack...and the tw barrels of a shotgun poke out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell goes there at two- thirty in the goddamn morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal, it's us! It's Paul and Brutal--it's us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings wider, revealing Hal's face gaunt and hag in the yellow porch light, stunned to see them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, what are you doing here at this hour? Jesus, it's not a lockdown, is it? Or a riot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal, God's sakes, take your finger off the trigger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal doesn't, aiming past them at the truck in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hostages? Who's out there? Who's by that truck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey steps into the glare of headlights with Harry tugg on his arm, trying to hold him back. Hal cocks both hamme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Coffey! Halt! Halt right there or I shoot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His aim wavers as a woman's voice comes from upstairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal? Who are you talking to, you fucking cocksucker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frozen moment. Hal mortified. Paul gives him a look--is that Melinda? Hal's shotgun shifts back to Coffey--but Paul steps in fr of the muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's hurt. We're here to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help what? I don't understand. Is this a prison break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't explain what it is. You just have to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey comes up the steps, brushes Paul aside, stops befo the warden. Hal blinks, his thoughts suddenly fuzzy--it's that benign hypnotic effect Coffey has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you...want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal! Make them go away! No salesmen in the middle of the night! No Fuller brushes! No French knickers with come in the crotch! Tell them to take a flying fuck in a rolling d...d...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of GLASS BREAKING, then she begins to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Just to help. Just to help, boss, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't. No one can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey pulls the shotgun gently from Hal's grasp, hands i Paul. Coffey moves past Hal into the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and comes up the hallway toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you go up there! Don't you do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss, you just be quiet now and let me be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey mounts the stairs with the others at his heels, heading up toward that quavering voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of here! Whoever you are, just stay out! I'm not dressed for visitors, you rat's asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey enters, trailed by the others. Paul pauses, horrif The woman propped in bed barely resembles Melinda Moores anymore--she looks made up like a Halloween witch, her li skin hanging in a loose trail of wrinkles, one corner of mouth twisted. Yellowish bile stains her chin and the fro of her nightgown. Her hair has gone white and straw-like, eyes glowering at Coffey with lively, irrational interest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so big! Pull down your pants! Let's have a look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal groans with despair. Coffey just stands there for a moment, watching her from a distance, then approaches the bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come near me, pigfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but as he draws closer, a change occurs. Her features soften, her eyes become more sane and aware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have so many scars? Who hurt you so badly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hardly remember, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey sits on the edge of the bed. The lights seem to fl hotter and brighter. Tears are forming in Melinda's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Coffey, ma'am. Like the drink, only not spelt the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lays back, staring at him with shining fascination. T world seems to be slowing down, growing very still indeed ...and he starts bending slowly toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, John Coffey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see it. I see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes closer...closer still...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be still now. You be so quiet and so still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brushes her forehead with his lips...the gentlest whis of a kiss...then moves his mouth down to hers. For a mome we can see one of her eyes staring past him, filling with expression of surprise... ...and then her face is lost to view as Coffey puts his l on hers. We hear a soft whistling sound as he begins inha the air deeply from her lungs. Something hot and glowing starts passing between them, drawn on his breath... The men watch. The house seems to shudder in that moment, if the entire world has shifted an inch to the right...

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS PARLOR
dialogues.text: ...and the grandfather clock stops ticking, the pendulum stopping dead, the glass face cracking neatly up the cent

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: ...and a windowpane cracks. Then another. A picture falls the wall. A lightbulb bursts, showering glass. Paul smells smoke, realizes the fringed coverlet of the b has caught fire. Moving like a man in a dream, he reaches the waterglass on the nightstand, douses the flames. Coffey keeps kissing Melinda in that deep and mysterious inhaling and inhaling, her hand held in his like a tiny w bird. For a moment we actually hear something screaming, if some willful imp were being extracted by force... ...and then it's over. Coffey raises his head, revealing: Melinda's beautiful face. Her mouth no longer droops. Col is coming back to her hair. Her skin is shining with life Coffey regards her raptly for a moment or two, then start coughing violently. He turns away and drops to his knees, hacking like a man the last stages of tuberculosis. Paul and his men are expecting Coffey to spit out the "bu but he doesn't--he just keeps coughing, deep and hard, ba finding time to snatch in the next breath of air. Hal goes to his wife, beyond stunned, sits at her side. S looks back at him with amazement, her face like a dirty mirror that's been suddenly wiped clean. John's coughing grows even worse. Brutal drops to his sid and slaps his broad, spasming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John! Sick it up! Cough 'em out like you done before!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey just keeps retching, eyes watering from the strain spit flying from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's choking! Whatever he sucked out of her, he's choking on it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul starts toward them. Coffey crawls away, pressing him into a corner with his face against the wallpaper. He's s making gruesome deep hacking sounds, but getting it under control. He weakly waves Paul off--let me be. Paul looks to the bed. Hal sits with Melinda, stroking he brow. Color is blooming in her cheeks even as we watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I get here? We were going to the hospital in Indianola, weren't we? We stopped and you bought me a packet of posies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh. It doesn't matter. It doesn't matter anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I have the X-ray? Did I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was clear. There was no tumor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal bursts into tears. Melinda sits up, comforting him. H eyes are drawn to the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey is struggling to rise. Brutal does his best to hel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John? Can you turn around? Can you turn around and see this lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey turns. His face is ashen gray, seriously ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Coffey, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the drink, only not spelled the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. Not spelt the same at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes the covers aside to rise. Hal tries to stop he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melly, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but she pushes his hand gently aside. Hal watches in wonder as she stands, takes a first tentative step...and walks to Coffey. She gazes up and touches his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamed of you. I dreamed you were wandering in the dark, and so was I. We found each other. We found each other in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She undoes her necklace, holds it up for him. He hesitate glances to Paul. Paul nods--it's all right. Coffey lowers head. Melinda affixes the delicate chain around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's St. Christopher. I want you to have it, Mr. Coffey, and wear it. He'll keep you safe. Please wear it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her arms go around his neck, hugging him tightly as if sh might never let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and the men hustle Coffey out the front door toward truck, helping him as best they can. He's weak as a baby, knees threatening to give out at any moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, John, stay on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, he goes down, we'll need three mules and a crane to pick him up again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get Coffey to the truck and throw their backs into i helping him crawl up onto the stakebed. He rolls over on back. Harry hops up, covers him with an old blanket. Brut pulls aside, speaking low:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll never sit in Old Sparky. You know that, don't you? (off Paul's look) He swallowed that stuff for a reason. I give him a few days. One of us'll be doing a cell check and there he'll be. Dead on his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's his choice, he's earned it. (beat) Let's get him back on the Mile.

dialogues.speaker: IN BLACKNESS, A TITLE CARD APPEARS
dialogues.text: "Coffey on the Mile"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean starts babbling with relief as they return:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I glad to see you! You were gone so long! Wild Bill's making noises like he's gonna wake up... (notices Coffey) What the hell's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's hurting, Dean. Hurting bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean jumps in, helps them steer Coffey into his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, we're gonna set you on your bunk now. Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey nods, sits heavily on the bunk. He lowers his head breath rasping like a rusted hinge. The guards step out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Mrs. Moores? Was it like the mouse? Was it a...you know...a miracle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul scans their faces. Smiles are traded. An exultant be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. I think we got away with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still gotta convince a certain somebody to keep his trap shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean hurries off to retrieve Percy's holster and baton. Brutal unlocks the restraint room door, swings it open. P is revealed sitting against the wall, glaring, his mouth still taped. Paul crouches down. Brutal joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk, not shout. I take the tape off, you gonna be calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy nods. Paul takes hold of the tape, preparing to yan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother always said if you do it fast, it won't hurt so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul rips the tape off. Percy's eyes water with pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess she was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me out of this nut-coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! Now! Right n--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul slaps him hard, knocks him sideways. Percy looks up, blinking in surprise. Paul grabs him, yanks him back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shut up and listen. You deserved to be punished for what you did to Del. You'll accept it like a man, or we'll make you sorry you were ever born. We'll tell people how you sabotaged Del's execution--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sabotaged!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and how you pissed yourself like a frightened little girl. Yes, we'll talk, that's a given--but, Percy, mind me now...we'll also see you beaten within an inch of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy blinks, unable to grasp that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know people, too, are you so foolish you don't realize that? People with friends and loved ones doing time in this prison. People who'd be happy to amputate you nose or your penis just so someone they care about could get an extra three hours in the exercise yard every week. (off Percy's look) Let bygones be bygones. Nothing's hurt so far but your pride...and nobody need ever know about that except the people in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens on the Mile, stays on the Mile. Always has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I be let out of this coat now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull him to his feet, undo the straps. He shrugs out the straitjacket and adjusts his clothes, trying to maint a shred of dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean hands them over. Percy smooths his hair and puts his on, starts strapping on his holster belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think it over, Percy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I intend to. I intend to think about it very hard. Starting right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy exits the restraint room. Brutal whispers to Paul:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll talk. Sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul nods with weary resignation--yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MILE
dialogues.text: Percy pauses near Coffey's cell, careless as always, gett his holster buckled--and a massive black arm grabs him through the bars. His SCREAM brings Paul and the others f the restraint room. Coffey's face is pressed so tight between his bars it loo like he's trying to push his head through. He draws his l back, baring his teeth in an awful sneer... Percy whacks him with his baton. Coffey barely seems to f it. He curls his free hand around the back of Percy's hea pulling him ever closer... ...and Percy's screams are muffled as their mouths come together. Coffey begins exhaling as if he'd held his brea for hours. Percy jerks like a fish on a hook, but can't g away. The men jump in, try to pry Percy loose, hollering Coffey to let him go. The black "insects" are flowing from Coffey to Percy, swirling into his mouth, up his nose, down his throat. Several lightbulbs explode in their steel cages up and do the Mile. Percy's baton drops from his nerveless fingers clatters to the floor, never to be picked up again. And then Coffey steps back, rubbing his mouth as if he's tasted something bad. The color has returned to his skin. Percy, however, is ashen gray. His expression is blank as sheet of paper, not a trace of awareness in his eyes. The men are stunned. Paul raises his hand to Percy's face snaps his fingers. Nothing. He tries again, clapping loud Percy reacts slightly, eyes fluttering, swaying a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, easy. You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy says nothing. He turns and walks slowly up the Mile his movements vacant and disjointed. He comes to a swayin stop at Wild Bill's cell...and turns slowly to look in. Wild Bill is coming painfully around, groggily clutching head. He looks up, see Percy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'a you looking at, you limp noodle? You wanna kiss my ass or suck my dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing for the longest moment. Percy just staring... ...and then he pulls his gun and empties it into Wild Bil fast as he can pull the trigger. BAM!BAM!BAM!BAM!BAM!BAM! Bill takes all six rounds in the chest, reeling back acro the cell. He hits the wall and slides down, leaving a sme his face registering a final look of stunned surprise. Paul and the other tackle Percy and bring him down, wrest the gun out of his hand. Dean is almost weeping:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, oh God, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy is flat on his back, staring up at nothing. The bla "bugs" come drifting out of nose and mouth, swirling in t air over his head. They turn white and disappear. The men are speechless. Paul turns, sees Coffey sitting o the floor at his bars, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punished them bad men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Wild Bill? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw in his heart. When he grab my arm, I saw what Wild Billy done. Saw plain as day. Can't hide what's in your heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Saw what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey reaches toward him, straining through the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my hand, boss. You see for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hesitates, torn between reason and Coffey's pleading eyes. A whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul can't help it. He has to. Their hands come together. Paul lurches wildly as that circuit starts blazing betwee them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gots to, boss. Gots to give you a little bit of myself. A gift, like. A gift of what's in me so you can see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Paul sees: The Detterick twins. Kathe and Cora. Laughing and playing hopscotch in the dust under a later afternoon sun... A dinner table. Family having supper late in the day, bas of biscuits being passed. Twelve year old Howie Detterick taking it, passing it on... An hand with a paint brush slopping bright red paint on t side of a barn... Kathe skipping to the head of the hopscotch squares, turn and starting back, laughing in the sun... The paint brush slopping more paint, dripping like blood. Paul jerks and twists, trying to pull away, trying to bre the circuit, but he can't, not till all is seen and done: Marjorie Detterick calling from the porch for everybody t come eat, supper's ready... A hammer pausing. Klaus looking down from atop the barn.. The Detterick twins finishing their hopscotch, gathering their jump ropes from the dust, running across the yard.. The basket of biscuits being passed to little Cora, who t a biscuit and passes it on... Klaus coming down the ladder, calling to his daughters. T little girls running past the man with the paint brush, w turns and smile as they go by...it's Wild Bill. The basket of biscuits is passed one last time. A hand pu one out, raises it for a bite. It's Wild Bill, smiling at little girls as conversation flows around the table... Paul screams, trying to pull away, but: The porch door is kicked off its hinges just before dawn, figure looming in the doorway. Kathe wakes, her scream cu short as the man's fist punches her hard in the face... Paul trembles violently as if riding the lightning himsel pleading for it to stop, but there's one last thing: Wild Bill looms over the terrified little girls like a horrendous boogeyman, whispers to Kathe:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lover your sister? You make any noise, know what happens? I'll kill her instead of you. (to Cora) And if you make any noise, I'll kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he drags them out into the coming dawn... ...as Coffey lets Paul go. Paul is gasping, back in the r world where his men are staring at him with wide eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kill 'em with they love. They love for each other. You see how it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul nods, numb. Tears are flowing down Coffey's face. So

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how it is ever' day. That's how it is all over the worl'...

dialogues.speaker: WILD BILL
dialogues.text: lies dead, staring with glassy eyes. A FLASHBULB POPS, rimming him with harsh blue light...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as Hal arrives, wearing his pajama top under his overc He sees the POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER taking pictures. The guar are giving statements to GROUPS OF COPS, everybody murmur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...well, I dunno, he just snapped, I guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...s'right, one minute he's fine, the next--blammo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...bastard grabbed him through the bars a few days back, scared the boy so bad he wet himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal turns, sees:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: sits handcuffed on the floor of the Mile, eyes glassier t Wild Bill's. TWO COPS are trying to snap him out of it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son! Son! Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up if you can hear us! We gotta ask you some questions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MEDIC is raising Percy's eyelid with his thumb, shining penlight, getting no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this boy's cheese slid off his cracker.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: sees Paul, motions him aside to talk privately:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll cover you as much as I can, even if it mean my job, but I have to know. Does this have anything to do with what happened at my house? Does it, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks Hal in the eye. As with Bitterbuck, the lie co easy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING A PAIR OF FEET shuffling into the room in hospit slippers, escorted by TWO ORDERLIES. The patient is broug to a window. The orderlies turn to leave... ...and we BOOM UP to reveal Percy, catatonic, staring out same window where we met Wild Bill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and we WIDEN SLOWLY from Percy at the window to reveal last stop in life. It's emblazoned on the gate: BRIAR RID MENTAL HOSPITAL. He finally got that transfer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON PAUL as softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes sense. I read the file. Hal even said it himself. Wharton rambled all over the state last few years, causing trouble. Hell, longer than that. Been at it since he was ten. Vandalism. Petty theft. Setting fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE SHIFTS to include Jan, Brutal, Harry and Dean. They in the brambly patch that borders the woods behind the ho The sun is setting, turning the horizon fiery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw him. You actually saw this Wild Bill person take those girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their father hired him on for a few days last spring, help repair the barn. Cheap labor, just another drifter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick bastard came back a month later, just before dawn. Took the girls...did what he did. Coffey found them afterwards and tried to help. It was too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absorbs this) Then you can stop it. The execution, I mean. Get Coffey a new trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Based on what, honey? Some kind of magical vision I had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show this farmer--what's his name, Detterick?--show him a picture of Wild Bill. (off their looks) Why not? If Wharton was there...if the farmer can identify his picture and they know he was there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him being there in May doesn't mean he came back and killed those girls in June. Even if he was committing other crimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got their killer as far as they're concerned. Hell, Coffey's own lawyer would come throw the switch if we let him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lie? About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them Wharton confessed to the crime. Brutus, you can back him up, say you heard it too. You can say that's what set Percy off. He shot Wharton because he couldn't stand thinking of what happened to those two little girls, it snapped his mind... (seeing their looks) ...what? What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never reported anything like that. We would've, too, everybody knows it. It's part of our job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, confessing don't make it so. Slugs like Wild Bill lie about everything. Crimes they committed, women they had, even the weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he was there! He painted their barn! He ate dinner with them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the more reason he might take credit for the crime. He's gonna fry anyway, so why not boast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan stands thinking for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Then you've got to get John Coffey out on your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it once, didn't you? Only this time, don't bring him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean blinks, stunned by this notion. Gently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, your son's grown up and moved away. My kids are just starting kindergarten. Will you be the one to explain to them why their daddy's in prison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work out a plan. Make it look like a real escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better be a plan an imbecile could dream up. Nobody'd believe it otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if we did think of something, it wouldn't do any good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Just why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's a six-foot-eight-inch baldheaded black man with barely enough brains to feed himself. How long you think it'd be before he was recaptured? Two hours? Six?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan swipes a tear away with the heel of her hand. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean to kill him, you cowards? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul tries to take her hand. She wrenches away, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me! Next week this time you'll be a murderer, no better than that man Wharton, so don't touch me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs off toward the house, starting to sob as we

dialogues.speaker: INT PAUL'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Paul is at the kitchen table in the wee hours, at his reg place, sipping his beer. Irving Berlin's "Remember" PLAYS SOFTLY on the radio. Jan comes down, looking miserable an exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry I called you a coward. I feel worse about that than anything I've ever said to you in our whole marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even that time we went camping and you called me Old Stinky Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't help smiling at that. He returns the smile, off her a sip of beer. She takes it, sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Hal know? That Coffey's innocent, I mean? (Paul shakes his head) Can he help? Does he have the influence to do something about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't tell him. If he can't help, don't tell him. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) There's no way out of this for you, is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I've been thinking about it, too, believe me. (beat) Tell you the truth, honey. I've done some things in my life I'm not proud of, but this is the first time I've ever felt in real danger of hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell? Oh Paul... (touches his face) Talk to him. Talk to John. Find out what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey sits quietly in his cell, a solitary firefly flitt in circles around his finger. Paul and the men appear. Th firefly flits away, vanishing through Coffey's tiny windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal unlocks his cell. Paul enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you know we're coming down to it now. Another couple of days. (beat) Is there anything special you'd like for dinner that night? We can rustle you up most anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey gives it some careful thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meatloaf be nice. Mashed taters with gravy. Okra, maybe. I's not picky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about a preacher? Someone you could say a little prayer with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want no preacher. You can say a prayer, if you want. I could get kneebound with you, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey gives him a look--please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'pose I could, if it came to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits, working himself up to it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, I have to ask you something very important right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you gonna say. You don' have to say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. I do have to. (beat) John, tell me what you want me to do. You want me to take you out of here? Just let you run away? See how far you can get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you do such a foolish thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hesitates, emotions swirling, trying to find the rig words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the day of my judgement, when I stand before God, and He asks me why did I kill one of his true miracles, what am I gonna say? That is was my job? My job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell God the Father it was a kindness you done. (takes his hand) I know you hurtin' and worryin', I can feel it on you, but you oughtta quit on it now. Because I want it over and done. I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey hesitates--now he's the one trying to find the rig words, trying to make Paul understand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired, boss. Tired of bein' on the road, lonely as a sparrow in the rain. Tired of not ever having me a buddy to be with, or tell me where we's coming from or going to, or why. Mostly I'm tired of people being ugly to each other. I'm tired of all the pain I feel and hear in the world ever' day. There's too much of it. It's like pieces of glass in my head all the time. Can you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now, Paul is blinking back tears. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, John. I think I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be something we can do for you, John. There must be something you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey thinks about this long and hard, finally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't never seen me a flicker show.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON COFFEY'S FACE
dialogues.text: gazing with wide-eyed, open-mouthed wonder, the light of motion picture projector flickering on his skin...

dialogues.speaker: INT PRISON AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: ...while Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers dance up there on big screen, images flowing in magical black and silver to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Heaven, I'm in heaven...and my heart beats so that I can hardly speak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and the men are scattered about in the otherwise emp auditorium, also watching.

dialogues.speaker: PROJECTION BOOTH
dialogues.text: Toot operates the projector, peering through the tiny win into the theater. He yawns, glances at his watch. Late.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: Fred and Ginger are now in the most passionate and gracef part of the dance. Irving Berlin's music swells.

dialogues.speaker: COFFEY
dialogues.text: can't believe what he's seeing. He's so excited his breat caught in his throat. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, they's angels. Angels. Just like up in heaven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR PAIRS OF FEET come marching up the Green Mile.

dialogues.speaker: COFFEY
dialogues.text: Paul appears at the bars with Brutal, Harry, and Dean. Nothing is said. Coffey knows why they're here. He rises Brutal unlocks the cell, slides the door open. Coffey ste out, looks around at their dazed and sad faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I be all right, fellas. This here's the hard part. I be all right in a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul indicates St. Christopher medal around John's neck:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, I should have that just for now. I'll give it back after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John lets him take the necklace. Paul pockets it. They st to walk the Mile as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I fell asleep this afternoon and had me a dream. I dreamed about Del's mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamed he got down to that place Boss Howell talked about, that Mouseville place. I dreamed there was kids, and how they laughed at his tricks! My!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs at the memory of it, then grows more serious:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamed those two little blonde- headed girls were there. They 'us laughing, too. I put my arms around 'em and sat 'em on my knees, and there 'us no blood comin' outta their hair and they 'us fine. We all watch Mr. Jingles roll that spool, and how we did laugh. Fit to bus', we was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind them, Dean stifles a sob.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL'S INNER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Coffey kneels. Paul joins him, self-conscious and uncerta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should we pray for, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strength?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul nods--strength it is. Dean surprises Brutal and Harr also kneeling. Brutal and Harry hesitate...then join them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, please help us finish what we've started, and please welcome this man, John Coffey--like the drink, but not spelled the same-- into heaven and give him peace. Please help us to see him off the best we can and let nothing go wrong. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul starts to rise, but Coffey takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a prayer I once heard. Can I say it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go right ahead, John. Take all the time you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey closes his eyes, frowning in deep concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby Jesus, meek and mild, pray for me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Paul sees: Kathe and Cora Detterick kneeling together in the enclose porch that night, just before their bedtime:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and every child. Be my strength, be my friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then the vision is gone as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...be with me until the end. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey rises, offers Paul his hand, helps him up.

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTION CHAMBER
dialogues.text: Full house tonight. Bill Dodge is waiting at Old Sparky. Silence as Coffey is led in, all eyes on him. Klaus and Marjorie Detterick are in the front row. She mutters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Die slow, you bastard.

dialogues.speaker: COFFEY
dialogues.text: is faltering as Paul and Brutal bring him to the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They's a lot of folks here hate me. A lot. I can feel it. Like bees stinging me. It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel how we feel, then. We don't hate you--can you feel that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffey tries to take comfort in it, but flinches as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him twice, you boys! You go on and kill that raping baby- killer twice, that'd be fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dissolves into tears. Klaus pulls her against his shoulder, looking dazed by the whole thing. Paul and Brutal turn John around, sit him down. Paul noti Dean crying again, his back to the witnesses. They kneel apply the leg clamps, while Brutal and Harry secure the a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wipe you face before you stand up, Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean nods, wiping his face with the sleeve of his coat. T rise, stepping back. This time, Paul's out front:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll on one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Hay cranks the generator. The lights flare hotter and brighter. It's just like in Melinda's bedroom the night Coffey cured her with a kiss. Airless and bright, dreamli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it hurt yet? I hope it does! I hope it hurts like hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Coffey...you have been condemned to die in the electric chair by a jury of your peers...sentence imposed by a judge in good standing in this state. Do you have anything to say before sentence is carried out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John hesitates, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for what I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to be! Oh, you monster, you damn well ought to be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal takes the mask from the hook to draw it over Coffe head. Coffey looks to Paul with terrified, pleading eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, boss, don't put that thing over my face. Don't put me in the dark, I's afraid of the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal puts the mask back, proceeds with the sponge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cap is lowered, the straps drawn. Coffey is breathing fast, terrified, muttering under his breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...heaven...I'm in heaven... heaven...heaven...heaven...

dialogues.speaker: THE WITNESSES
dialogues.text: sit and wait, barely breathing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK VAN HAY
dialogues.text: is poised at the switch, wondering why the order won't co

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: is staring at Coffey, unable to say the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Paul. You have to say it. You have to give the order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul can't. He reaches out and touches Coffey's hand. The fingers clasp. In that moment, staring into his eyes, Pau hears the last thought that ever goes through Coffey's he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered V.O.) He kill 'em with they love. That's how it is ever' day. All over the worl'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their fingers disengage. Paul steps back, eyes still lock with Coffey's, and says the hardest words he's ever spoke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll on two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Hay throws the switch. Coffey surges forward, fingers splayed and jittering past Old Sparky's arms. Lights begin blowing out all over the Mile, raining shatt glass and sparks. Some of the witnesses scream. A thin line of blood comes trickling out of Klaus Detteri nose. He reaches up, absently wipes it away. Coffey's eyes are locked on Paul's, riding the lightning the way. He finally slumps. Van Hay kills the current. Coffey's expression is peaceful, as if sleeping. A final of tears drift gently down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul ever so carefully replaces the St. Christopher's med around Coffey's neck. They wheel him down the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul drives home, his heart numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul pulls in, cuts the engine. He sits for a moment, the gets out and heads for the house. The door opens. Jan steps out in her nightgown and robe t meet him on the stairs. She takes him in her arms. Paul can't hold it back anymore. He breaks down sobbing against her as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late in the day as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the last execution I ever took part in. Just couldn't do it anymore after that. Brutal either. We both transferred out, took jobs with Boys' Correctional. (beat, nods) That was all right. Catch 'em young, that became my motto. Might even have done some good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE SHIFTS TO Elaine listening. Uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't imagine you would lie to me, Paul. It's just that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's quite a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Quite a story. (pause) One thing I don't understand. You said you and Jan had a grownup son in 1935. Is that right? (Paul nods) But if that's true...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The math doesn't work, does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head. Paul thinks for a moment, comes to a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel up to a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has mostly stopped. Brad Dolan, back in street clothes, gets in his pickup truck and drives away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...while Paul and Elaine watch from a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, we see two red specks trudging slowly up the r toward the treeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul brings Elaine along the wooded path into view of the storage shacks. They're both wearing ponchos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. It's in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? This thing you want to show me. Is it scary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scary? No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a smile, offers his hand. She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Paul approach through the grimy window as before, time bringing Elaine. ANGLE SHIFTS to the door as they arrive, creaking open on rusty hinges to reveal them. They enter. Elaine looks around at the musty nooks and crannies, wondering what they're doing here. Paul toucher arm, directs her attention:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine moves closer, sees it on the dusty floorboards: An old cigar box. For a moment, she doesn't know what to make of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Wake up, old boy. Wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine's breath catches in her throat... ...as a pair of bright oilspot eyes peer over the edge of cigar box. It's a mouse. His fur, once brown, is now all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? It isn't...it can't be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul gets down on the floor, holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over here, boy. Come on over her and see this lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mouse tries several times to get over the side of the cigar box before he finally makes it. He comes to them, hobbling and crippled with arthritis. Paul pulls a slice toast from his pocket, breaks off a small piece for the m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can't be Mr. Jingles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul says nothing, just pulls a spool from his pocket. Mr Jingles might be old, but he's as obsessed as ever. He ge ready to fetch, eyes riveted to the spool. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Messieurs et mesdames. Beinvenue au cirque du mousie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul tosses the spool. The mouse limps painfully after it reaches it, goes around...and has to lay down to catch hi breath. Elaine starts forward, but Paul holds her back. After a moment, Mr. Jingles finds his feet again. He rise and starts nosing the spool back to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Paul. Don't make him do it again. I can't bear to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) But he loves it so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances around at the shack with a sad smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't exactly the Mouseville we had in mind...but we make do, don't we, old fella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I live and breathe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gasp and spin. Brad Dolan stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fooled you, didn't I Got yourself a little love nest here, I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, seeing Mr. Jingles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what the fuck? Is that a mouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hurt him, okay? Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a goddamn mouse, y'old fool, they carry all kind'a disease...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad grabs an old garden hoe--the blade's rusted, but sti sharp enough to cut a mouse in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...now step aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul rushes in front of Brad, fists clenched, yelling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave him alone, Percy! You leave him alone, or by God I'll--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad gives Paul a hard shove, pins him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you calling Percy? Name's Brad, you senile fucker. And I'm gonna nail that mouse, you can take that to the everfucking bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is suddenly at Brad's elbow, seething with fury:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you? Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piss off, you wrinkeldy old bitch. Me and Paulie are talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Mr. Edgecomb. If you ever call him Paulie again, your days of employment at Georgia Pines will end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the grandmother of the man who is currently Speaker of the Georgia House of Representatives. A man who loves his relatives, Mr. Dolan. All it would take is a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad's smile falters. Elaine steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first I thought I'd let you be. I'm old, and that seemed easiest. But when my friends are threatened and abused, I do not let it be. (icy beat) Now get out, or you won't work another day here. Not another hour. I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad eases his grip on Paul...and backs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know what you're getting so het up about. Just a damn mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out, you ignorant man. What little mind you have is ugly and misdirected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad flushes red, heads for the door. He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother coming back here tomorrow...Mr. Edgecomb Gonna be a new lock on this door. This is off-limits to residents, no matter what Mrs. My Shit Don't Stink has to say about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And off he goes. Paul tries to control the shaking in his hands, looks to Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little trick I learned from Percy Wetmore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your grandson really Speaker of the House?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul bends down, picks Mr. Jingles up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna thank the lady? She just saved your old mousie hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mouse stretches his neck forward, nose twitching, smelling Paul's breath. Paul looks to Elaine. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Mr. Jingles happened by accident. I think when we electrocuted Del, and it all went so badly...well, John could feel it, you know...and I think a tiny part of whatever was inside of him just leapt out... (beat) Me, I was no accident. John had to give me a little part of himself...a gift, like...so I could see for myself what Wild Bill had done. When John did that, a part of whatever power worked through him spilled into me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He...what? Infected you with life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks at the mouse, strokes him gently between the e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's as good a word as any. He infected us both, didn't he, Mr. Jingles. With life. (beat) I'm a hundred and five years old, Elaine. I was forty the year John Coffey walked the Green Mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PUSHES SLOWLY IN on Paul as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't even had a cold since 1935. I've had to watch my friends and loved ones die off through the years...Hal and Melinda...Brutus Howell...my wife...my son... (beat) ...and you, Elaine. You'd die, too, and my curse is knowing I'll be there to see it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, dressed in a dark suit, comes up the aisle. ANGLE SHIFTS to reveal Elaine Connelly lying in the open casket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that's my punishment, you see? My punishment for letting John Coffey ride the lightning...for killing a miracle of God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul lays a rose atop the casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you'll be gone, like all the others, and I'll have to stay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stands at the graveside as the casket is lowered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll die eventually, I imagine. I have no illusions of immortality. But I will have wished for death long before death finds me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In truth, I wish for it already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty and silent. Young Paul walks the Mile alone, listen to the quiet. He pauses, seeing something. A whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jingles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Mr. Jingles. The little mouse is peering from under restraint room door. He's come home, looking bedraggled. bends down, gently picks him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been, boy? I've been worried about you. You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul turns and head back up the Green Mile, carrying the mouse cupped in his hands as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Paul transforms into Old Paul in the dissolve, the corridor of the Green Mile becoming the corridor of the nursing home. He's walking along, holding the little mous the same way he did over sixty years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lie in bed most nights, thinking about it. And I wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul lies awake, staring at the moon outside his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think about all the people I've loved, now long gone. I think about my beautiful Jan, and how I lost her so many years ago. I think about all of us walking our own Green Mile, each in our own time. But one thought, more than any other, keeps me awake most nights...
